fields.standfirst:
• Premier League updates from the 5.30pm BST kick-off
  • Chelsea 2-2 Man Utd: late leveller sparks touchline chaos
  • And feel free to email your thoughts to Scott here
fields.trailText: Minute-by-minute report: Join Scott Murray for all the action from the Premier League meeting in Yorkshire
fields.body:
5.39pm BST

8 min: Alisson passes long. Salah cushions a header down to Sturridge, who is in a lot of space in the Huddersfield half. Lallana is ahead, ready to spring clear into the box, but perpetual motion is his downfall; as Sturridge plays the pass forward, he‚Äôs inexplicably spun round the wrong way, and hasn‚Äôt a clue where the ball is.

5.36pm BST

6 min: Depoitre romps down the right and centres. Billing shuttles the ball to the left for Durm, who has space but hesitates. He‚Äôs closed down by Gomez and the chance of getting a shot on goal is lost.

5.35pm BST

4 min: A throw for Huddersfield down the left. Billing will launch it long. In a packed area, Lovren gets his head on it and clears.

5.34pm BST

3 min: Sturridge embarks on a power dribble down the middle. He evades a couple of challenges then rolls a pass to the left for Salah. There‚Äôs too much juice on it, and though Salah manages to retain possession, he‚Äôs forced miles to the wing and the move breaks down.

5.33pm BST

2 min: Still super-hectic. Nobody‚Äôs managed to control the ball yet, never mind string a few passes together.

5.32pm BST

And we‚Äôre off! Liverpool get the party started. A hug between Wanger and Klopp on the touchline; a thundering atmosphere in the stands. All very scrappy at the start in the midfield; a couple of misdirected throws, a couple of misplaced headers. The only way is up!

5.26pm BST

No pre-match word with David Wagner, which is a shame. He was caught on camera earlier sharing smiles and high fives with his old buddy Jurgen, so at least we know he‚Äôs in high spirits. Anyway, the teams are on the pitch, Huddersfield in their grand old blue and white stripes, Liverpool sporting their equally storied red. We‚Äôll be off in two shakes of a Terrier‚Äôs tail. ‚ÄúCall me paranoid,‚Äù adds suspicion‚Äôs Hubert O‚ÄôHearn, ‚Äúbut I‚Äôm incredibly nervous about this match. It‚Äôs just the sort of away fixture that Liverpool have stumbled over in the past. Post-international break, motivated opponents, assorted injuries, Dejan Lovren starting ... Dejan Lovren starting!?!? I hope we hold it to a draw.‚Äù

Updated at 5.26pm BST

5.18pm BST

Jurgen Klopp speaks! ‚ÄúKeita and Mane‚Äôs injuries are not too serious, they shouldn‚Äôt be out too long. But I am happy with the line-up, we have a strong bench. We are aware that this will be a difficult game. Huddersfield are only not in a good moment results-wise; all the rest was good in the last few weeks. We need to be ready. Lallana has trained good, he was quite impressive all week. If he could take that onto the pitch it would be good!‚Äù

5.10pm BST

Pre-match reading. If you missed this, you missed out. Rob Smyth on one of the greatest goals ever scored at Anfield.

Related: Golden Goal: John Barnes for Liverpool v QPR (1987)

4.40pm BST

Huddersfield make one change to the team sent out for the 1-1 draw at Burnley a fortnight ago. Rajiv van La Parra makes way so Florent Hadergjonaj can bolster the defence.

Liverpool make three changes to the side named against Manchester City before the break. Like his half-brother van La Parra, Georginio Wijnaldum drops to the bench, along with Roberto Firmino. Sadio Mane is injured. Taking their places: Adam Lallana, Daniel Sturridge and Xherdan Shaqiri.

Updated at 5.32pm BST

4.32pm BST

The teams

Huddersfield Town: Lossl, Jorgensen, Schindler, Lowe, Hadergjonaj, Mooy, Hogg, Billing, Durm, Pritchard, Depoitre.
Subs: Bacuna, Diakhaby, Hamer, van La Parra, Mbenza, Mounie, Stankovic.

Liverpool: Alisson, Gomez, Lovren, van Dijk, Robertson, Lallana, Henderson, Milner, Salah, Sturridge, Shaqiri.
Subs: Fabinho, Wijnaldum, Firmino, Mignolet, Origi, Matip, Alexander-Arnold.

Referee: Michael Oliver (Northumberland).

4.04pm BST

Preamble

You could argue that the international break came at the wrong time for Huddersfield Town. A fortnight ago, David Wagner‚Äôs troops drew at Burnley, and on the balance of play they should have registered their first win of the season. It was a ‚Äúbrave and confident‚Äù display, according to Wagner. Slim pickings, admittedly, but when you‚Äôre struggling at the wrong end of the table, you grab any positives going with both hands. However a chance to build some precious momentum was scuppered by the quirks of the calendar.

The break probably came at the right time for Liverpool. After opening the season with seven straight wins, they‚Äôve not won in four, a run that‚Äôs seen them knocked out of the League Cup and pitched into a real dogfight in the Champions League. Given that winless streak comprised of games against Chelsea (twice), Napoli and Manchester City, and they‚Äôre still in the mix at the top of the Premier League, this hardly constitutes a full-blown crisis. But they‚Äôve not been at their freewheeling best, so the opportunity to stop and take stock will have been welcomed by Jurgen Klopp.

The Liverpool boss will be glad to see his old pal Warner. The Reds beat Huddersfield home and away last season, 3-0 on both occasions. Huddersfield haven‚Äôt beaten Liverpool since 1959. And they‚Äôve yet to score at home in 2018-19. Chelsea, Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur have all tamed the Terriers this season; Liverpool are expected to join that top-six list today. Then again, they‚Äôve not been totally dependable in seemingly lop-sided situations like this; they dropped nine points last season against the three teams eventually relegated, for example, a fact that will give Warner and his men succour as they look to cause a shock. It‚Äôs Huddersfield v Liverpool. It‚Äôs the Bill Shankly derby. It‚Äôs on!

Kick off: 5.30pm BST.

results.webTitle: Sarri says Chelsea to blame for sparking scuffle as Mourinho accepts apology

fields.headline: Sarri says Chelsea to blame for sparking scuffle as Mourinho accepts apology
fields.standfirst:
‚Ä¢ Sarri: assistant coach made ‚Äòbig mistake‚Äô provoking Portuguese
‚Ä¢ Mourinho says Ianni‚Äôs actions were down to ‚Äòbad education‚Äô
fields.trailText: Maurizio Sarri has apologised to Manchester United and admitted Chelsea were in the wrong after his assistant coach Marco Ianni goaded Jos√© Mourinho following Ross Barkley‚Äôs equaliser
fields.body:
Maurizio Sarri apologised to Manchester United and admitted Chelsea were in the wrong after one of his coaches sparked a furious touchline row with Jos√© Mourinho.

Related: Chelsea‚Äôs late leveller against Manchester United sparks touchline chaos around Mourinho

Mourinho leapt from his seat on United‚Äôs bench to confront Marco Ianni after Sarri‚Äôs assistant coach celebrated Ross Barkley‚Äôs dramatic late equaliser for Chelsea by pumping his fists in front of the away dugout at Stamford Bridge. The dispute spiralled into the tunnel, forcing stewards to intervene, and led to heated exchanges between members of both benches.

It was a while before Mike Dean, the referee, was able to restore order. Once the dust had settled, however, Sarri was quick to accept the blame and criticise Ianni‚Äôs actions. Mourinho, who accused Chelsea‚Äôs fans of disrespecting him, also attempted to draw a line under the matter despite saying that Ianni‚Äôs actions were down to a ‚Äúbad education‚Äù.

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt see anything on the pitch but after the match I spoke with Jos√© and immediately understood that we are wrong,‚Äù Sarri said. ‚ÄúI have spoken with the member of my staff and then I bring him to speak with Mourinho to say sorry to him. I think it is finished. We made a mistake. We were in the wrong.‚Äù

Sarri is yet to decide if he is will punish Ianni. ‚ÄúI have dealt with the situation immediately,‚Äù the Italian said. ‚ÄúI have to speak to him again because I want to be sure he is able to understand that it was a big mistake. I have to view everything. Now the situation is between me and the staff face to face.‚Äù

There were so many bodies involved that it was difficult for Dean to get a good view of what happened. The Football Association will have to wait for Dean‚Äôs report and view the footage before deciding whether to discipline either club.

It is thought that Mourinho meant that Ianni was guilty of a lack of manners when he spoke about the Italian‚Äôs education. In any case, United‚Äôs manager was not in a mood to prolong the argument.

‚ÄúNot celebrations, bad education,‚Äù the Portuguese said. ‚ÄúBut I also made mistakes in football matches and will make more. I accepted his apologies. Maurizio saw and said he would take care of it internally and to accept his apology, which I did. Then the young fellow came and apologised and I told him I accepted. I said: ‚ÄòI did mistakes when I was your age‚Äô.‚Äù

Related: Chelsea 2-2 Manchester United: how the players rated at Stamford Bridge

United were on the verge of securing their first win at Stamford Bridge since 2012 after mounting an impressive comeback in the second half, with Anthony Martial scoring twice after Antonio R√ºdiger had given Chelsea an early lead. Yet Mourinho ended up questioning why Dean played so much stoppage time after Barkley snatched a point for the hosts in the 96th minute. ‚ÄúThe referee gave six minutes,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúNormally when I am losing I never get six minutes. I do not know where the extra time came from. But that is football.‚Äù

United, who host Juventus in the Champions League on Tuesday, showed enough promise to suggest that Mourinho still has the support of his players after weeks of speculation about his future at Old Trafford. Martial was excellent in the second half and Mourinho refused to criticise Paul Pogba for losing R√ºdiger when the Chelsea defender headed in the opening goal from a corner.

‚ÄúMy feeling is that we work on the pitch,‚Äù Mourinho said. ‚ÄúWe defend mixed, so some players are in zones and some have individual opponents. Sometimes the opponent is better than us. In this case Antonio was really strong in the movement. Players make mistakes. I prefer to focus on the global performance. My midfield was very good. Paul was good.‚Äù

It was an eventful return to his former club for Mourinho. After the final whistle he held up three fingers to signify the number of league titles he won across two spells at Stamford Bridge. ‚ÄúI did not get respect back from Chelsea fans but that is not my responsibility,‚Äù Mourinho said.

results.webTitle: People's Vote march: '700,000' rally for new Brexit referendum ‚Äì live

fields.headline: People's Vote march: '700,000' rally for new Brexit referendum ‚Äì live
fields.standfirst:
Organisers say hundreds of thousands turned out on Saturday in central London for the ‚Äòsecond most attended demonstration this century‚Äô

  • Why the lies, Boris? The best banners from the march
  • The Observer view on the urgent need for a fresh vote on Europe
fields.trailText: Organisers say 700,000 turned out on Saturday in central London for the ‚Äòsecond most attended demonstration this century
fields.body:
5.36pm BST

The organisers of today‚Äôs march now estimate that there were 700,000 people demonstrating. This is one for the history books.

5.32pm BST

Jessica Elgot, the Guardian‚Äôs political correspondent, wonders why today‚Äôs Leave Means Leave rally was held in Harrogate - one of the few places to back remain in Yorkshire.

Meanwhile, Farage allegedly jumped the queue for the bar ahead of the event. His is a pint of bitter.

5.27pm BST

Guy Verhofstadt, the Belgian politicians who has been intimately involved in Brexit negotiations, has said that while the UK may leave the EU ‚Äúit won‚Äôt stop people feeling European‚Äù.

5.20pm BST

Jacob Rees-Mogg, perhaps predictably, has given the march short shrift:

Updated at 5.26pm BST

5.15pm BST

The march is officially over, but the streets are still jam-packed.

Here are a few more photos we missed earlier:

Updated at 5.21pm BST

5.01pm BST

The Labour MP Chuka Umunna, whose Lambeth constituency was the most pro-remain in England at the referendum, criticised Brexiters who ‚Äúhave tried to smear us as some liberal metropolitan elite, when nothing could be further from the truth‚Äù.

Right from the start of this debate they tried to set different parts of our United Kingdom against each other. They wanted to divide this country. And the truth is, whether you are from a remain or leave area, the problems are the same.

Whether you are from Liverpool, Lincoln, Llandudno, Livingston in Scotland or Lambeth, where I am, Brexit is not going to make those problems better. It is going to make them worse.

The deal on the table is nowhere near as good as the deal we‚Äôve got now.

Updated at 5.08pm BST

4.54pm BST

The standup comic John Bishop pleads with the government in all seriousness:

Updated at 4.56pm BST

4.50pm BST

Sadiq Khan notes the diversity of the crowd:

Updated at 4.57pm BST

4.44pm BST

The comedian Dom Joly contrasted today‚Äôs rally with last Saturday‚Äôs march by the far-right Football Lads Democratic Alliance.

Updated at 4.54pm BST

4.41pm BST

Addressing the crowd in Parliament Square earlier, the Lib Dem leader, Vince Cable, said it was ‚Äúa tragedy this country is being divided by generation‚Äù.

He said it was the majority of his generation that voted to leave, taking the freedom away from young voters. ‚ÄúThere is no deal better than the one we have now. It is better for Britain and better for Europe,‚Äù he said to cheers.

Following his speech, Cable added: ‚ÄúI think people have woken up to the potential disaster. Even if they negotiate a deal, it‚Äôs going to be a bad deal, where we‚Äôre going to spend years under European Union rules but have no say in them and beyond that there‚Äôs a cliff edge.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve realised there isn‚Äôt a good deal coming out of this and a lot of people are frightened, people are worried.‚Äù

Updated at 4.59pm BST

4.33pm BST

From Brexcrement and Brexshit to a Banksy-inspired placard, here are the best banners of the day.

Related: Why the lies, Boris? The best banners from the People's Vote march

Updated at 5.00pm BST

4.23pm BST

The Observer journalist Carole Cadwalladr, whose series of stories caused Facebook‚Äôs share value to tumble and Cambridge Analytica to fold, is being trumpeted as a future prime minister.

Stranger things have happened ...

Updated at 4.26pm BST

4.18pm BST

The Green party MP Caroline Lucas described the huge crowd as a beautiful sight.

What a movement we have become. The Green party is proud to be part of this amazing movement for a people‚Äôs vote, because we know that democracy didn‚Äôt end on the 23 June 2016. That referendum wasn‚Äôt the end of the story. It was the start of something new.

[Brexit] would make our poorest communities even poorer and more powerless. We must have that people‚Äôs vote, but we must also re-programme an economy that fails so many, that is based on such inequality, that condemns us to climate breakdown.

Updated at 4.23pm BST

4.09pm BST

Another roundup of photos from today, with a video from Anna Soubry‚Äôs speech.

The Conservative MP Anna Soubry told crowds in Parliament Square that ‚Äúit is clear we are the many‚Äù and that ‚Äúwe will take responsibly and sort out this mess‚Äù.

Updated at 4.47pm BST

4.02pm BST

More protesters have told our reporter about their fears of a no-deal Brexit and the potential effect it could have on peace in Ireland, the economy, and LGBT rights.

Peter, 60, from Crawley, had created a large banner that read: ‚ÄúWould an honourable country renege on a peace treaty? No hard border in Ireland.‚Äù While he‚Äôs not Irish, Peter said: ‚ÄúI remember the Troubles from the 70s. That‚Äôs no reason to take the status quo for granted. People forget too soon the benefits of the Good Friday agreement.‚Äù

He said it filled him with despair to hear people talk of scrapping the Good Friday agreement in the hopes of a clean exit out of the EU. ‚ÄúThe whole Irish economy could be so badly affected and then you look at history and the way we‚Äôve treated them in the past, it‚Äôs a bit of a rough deal for them. They deserve better treatment from us.‚Äù

Derick, 35, who lives in London, was waving an rainbow flag and marching with an LGBT group. He said he had come to the march because he was ‚Äúconcerned that this might be one of the last opportunity to get through how serious the situation is‚Äù.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs pretty terrifying and I‚Äôm transgender and basically most of my rights as a person has come from the EU. If we leave the EU, I am liable to not become a person,‚Äù he said.

Matthew Cooke, 28, who had come down from Scunthorpe with the Modern Union for a Changing World, described the prospect of a no-deal Brexit as ‚Äúterrifying‚Äù.

‚ÄúBrexit in its guise is no good for jobs, no good for workers rights and no good for people‚Äôs finance,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt would be remiss not to be out here to not get a better future for everybody.‚Äù Cooke, who has worked as both a steelworker and a trade unionist, said it was the duty of the union to fight to get better deals for their workers.

Updated at 4.24pm BST

3.50pm BST

Nicola Sturgeon, the SNP leader, just addressed the crowd at Parliament Square via video link.

Updated at 3.53pm BST

3.42pm BST

It appears that Rachel Johnson, sister of the former foreign secretary, attended the march in London today.

Like Boris, Jason Gillot, a 43-year-old Londoner who is on the march today, also changed his mind significantly on Brexit ‚Äì albeit slightly after Boris. Gillot originally voted to leave the EU, but said he changed his mind five days after the referendum.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm politically agnostic but I was just sick of the lies that have come out of both sides,‚Äù he said, going on to explain he initially voted to leave due to ‚Äúeconomic evidence partly supplied by the Tax Payers‚Äô Alliance‚Äù which ‚Äúmade sense at the time‚Äù.

‚ÄúNow we have actual facts and realities of what‚Äôs going to be happening,‚Äù he said. Gillot has been marching with a sign that says ‚ÄúWhen the facts change, I change my mind! What do you do sir?‚Äù

Updated at 3.48pm BST

3.41pm BST

1,200 people attend Leave Means Leave rally

Elsewhere, in Harrogate, at the Leave Means Leave rally there are reportedly 1,200 people in attendance.

Sky have reported that Nigel Farage claimed ‚Äúmillions‚Äù of people were streaming the pro-Brexit events; however, on Twitter, 190 people are watching the Harrogate event, while there are 12,000 views on its Facebook stream.

3.28pm BST

Aerial footage shows thousands of protesters on the march

3.24pm BST

The tail of the protest has now moved on to Piccadilly, far later than planned, indicating the scale of the turnout today.

ITV‚Äôs Robert Peston has tried to give us all a sense of the size of the march.

Updated at 3.27pm BST

3.22pm BST

The Metropolitan police have said today‚Äôs march has passed without incident, in spite of the sheer size of the demonstration. A spokesperson said they were not aware of any arrests and there had been no criminal disruption.

The scale of today‚Äôs protest places it in the upper echelons of protests since the millennium. A march organised by the Countryside Alliance in 2002 calling for Liberty & Livelihood reportedly attracted more than 400,000 people, while the TUC‚Äôs March for the Alternative anti-cuts protest in 2011 also saw around 400,000 people take to the streets.

Diana Luck, from Muswell Hill, is one of many women on the march carrying various homemade ‚Äòangry granny‚Äô signs. Her‚Äôs simply reads ‚ÄúVery Angry Grandmother‚Äù. ‚ÄúI am very angry at the things that are happening like Brexit and Trump and very worried about the future for my children and grandchildren,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs true for all of us angry grannies.‚Äù She added she was marching because democracy was being eroded and the things she believes in, like the NHS, were being threatened. Meanwhile, Joe Trickey, from Croydon, is celebrating his 83rd birthday at the march. ‚ÄúI believe very strongly in the EU as a place of peace and strength,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúGoing out puts us in isolation and leaving isn‚Äôt about trade deals, it‚Äôs about our values.‚Äù Trickey is protesting alongside his daughter, who is holding a sign about his birthday, and plans to celebrate afterwards with ‚Äúa glass of wine‚Äù. A brief reminder on what may have compelled people to take to the streets in droves today. Nicola Sturgeon, the first minister of Scotland, has sent a surprise video message of support to the rally promising that the SNP‚Äôs 35 MPs would give their unconditional backing for a people‚Äôs vote. Let me say this loudly and clearly, if the issue comes before the House of Commons, SNP MPs will support a people‚Äôs vote which includes the option to remain in the EU. The leave campaign has already gone down in history as one of most disingenuous, dishonourable and downright dishonest electoral contests of modern times. Those responsible should be utterly ashamed of themselves. Instead of a coherent vision and clear prospectus setting out what a vote to leave the EU would mean, all we got was waffle and that infamous lie on the side of a bus. Incredible though it may seem, things since then have got even worse. The Tory government‚Äôs handling of these negotiations has been chaotic, incompetent and shambolic. Having spent two years telling us that no deal was better than a bad deal, the prime minister is now preparing to pile pressure on MPs to vote for a bad or blindfold deal on the grounds that ‚Äòno deal‚Äô would be catastrophic. She is trying to scare the UK into the frying pan out of fear of the fire. It is a scandal and it should not be accepted. There are still thousands of people at Hyde Park corner stuck in a jam before they are expected to make their way down Piccadilly. It appears that the police dramatically under-estimated the number of marchers, but they are being kept happy with various chants and a sound system blaring out Kraftwerk‚Äôs TransEurop Express. The march is finally moving, but progressing incredibly slowly. It‚Äôs frequently stopping and starting. The roads are rammed with protesters, many of whom are happily dancing along to the samba band. Louise Penn, who travelled down from Norfolk, was pleased that so many people had turned up. ‚ÄúWe brought London to a standstill and that‚Äôs a message in of itself,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing this partly for myself, but for my children and their children. This is for the future of the country.‚Äù Peter De Clercq, 39, came down with Penn on the same bus. He said at the last people‚Äôs vote march there was only one bus coming down from Norfolk, but this morning there was six buses full of protesters heading to London. He was incredibly happy with the turnout. De Clercq, who is originally from Belgium, said that after living in the UK for 18 years he felt he was suddenly being stripped of his right. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm losing my rights. I can‚Äôt vote. I didn‚Äôt have a vote before and we all deserve the vote,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm doing this for every European citizen, including the British.‚Äù Protesters have brought traffic to a standstill in central London as the march proves far more popular than initially expected. David Mitchell, chairman of the Enfield Liberal Democrat group, suggested the large turnout it was partly down to how negotiations had floundered in recent weeks. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs due partly to how the negotiations have gone in the past six months, but it‚Äôs also a credit to the European movement who have really got themselves organised,‚Äù he said, describing the group of protesters at today‚Äôs march as twice as many than at the march in June. ‚ÄúEnfield overwhelmingly voted to stay in the EU and we want to make it clear that Enfield is committed to staying in the European Union. ‚ÄúThe polls are showing that we voted to have a go at this process, it hasn‚Äôt worked, so now the people need to have a say on how we‚Äôre going with it,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs now or never really, we‚Äôre getting to crunch time.‚Äù More photos from the march: Organisers are heralding the largest Brexit demonstration yet as 570,000 people come together for the People‚Äôs Vote march. The campaign has stewards stationed at regular intervals to estimate the size of the vast crowd that backed up Park Lane and spilled into Hyde Park before setting off toward Piccadilly and a mass rally in Parliament Square. ‚ÄúShortly after midday the sheer weight of number forced the closure of not only the southbound but also the northbound carriage way of Park Lane as the size of the crowd soared far above the massive march for a People‚Äôs Vote in June this year,‚Äù said a spokesperson. ‚ÄúThis makes it the second biggest demonstration this century behind the 1 million estimated to have protested against the Iraq War in 2003.‚Äù Activist Adam Bradford, one of the leading voices in the young People‚Äôs Vote and founder of group Brexit by Under 30s, says we face a bleak future and young voices need amplifying. Young voices need amplifying in the Brexit debate and the misconceptions around what a People‚Äôs Vote really means need to be unravelled. I feel like the government does not constitutionally have the mandate to change the country in this way overnight, I am feeling vulnerable as an employer of EU citizens and now the government is turning inwards we are facing a bleak future. We have this rhetoric coming from Downing Street which keeps saying it is delivering on the ‚Äúwill of the people‚Äù and we are in a situation where the government is trying to force through a deal that is being held up like this is something we voted to do. But people actually voted whether to leave or remain in the EU. We didn‚Äôt vote for this Segway into a hard Brexit with the outcome unknown. The government does not have the mandate to fundamentally change the country overnight. Before we actually had the vote, we should have been better informed and we should have been immediately aware of what leaving would mean. The government is closed off to what people are saying, it is turning its back on our concerns and turning inwards. We are not Brexiteers and we are not ‚Äúremoaners‚Äù. We just want to know how we will be supported. The government is playing politics with the next generation‚Äôs future. On the march, Elena Remigi, founder of the In Limbo project, has spoken of the ‚Äúturmoil‚Äù EU citizens in Britain and Brits residing in the EU have been in since the Brexit vote. As part of the project, the group has collected testimonies from both groups and published two books. ‚ÄúIt tells of the turmoil after the 2016 referendum and the fact our rights haven‚Äôt been guaranteed,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe have been used as bargaining chips and now we risk becoming collateral damage.‚Äù Meanwhile, Peter Andrews - who was among the 500 people to have travelled to London with the group Bath for Europe - said that Brexit will ruin his children‚Äôs future. ‚ÄúWe must have a people‚Äôs vote,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI believe leaving Europe is the stupidest idea I have ever come across. It will ruin my children‚Äôs future and it will ruin my future.‚Äù Andrews, who was handing out fake bank notes with Jacob Rees-Mogg‚Äôs face on, added that ‚ÄúBritain is being led by extreme right wing fanatics.‚Äù The group issued several notes, including a 350 million note. Rees-Mogg‚Äôs face had been chosen to be plastered on a 50 Guineas note because he was trying ‚Äúto take us back in time,‚Äù Andrews said. Whether the notes will be accepted as legal tender, a la Banksy‚Äôs 2004 Di-Faced Tenner stunt, remains to be seen. This is rather good. The actor and seasoned campaigner Hugh Grant has tweeted his regret that he could not attend today‚Äôs march. Some of Grant‚Äôs contemporaries, however, were able to make it. The Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, who campaigned for remain but was part of the anti-EU Bennite faction of the party before his rapid rise, is also absent from today‚Äôs march: Four packed coaches set off at 9am from Birmingham, which voted marginally in favour of Brexit in 2016, to carry people to the march in London. At 12.30pm they arrived on Park Lane and the passengers, kitted out with EU flags, T-shirts, banners, badges and whistles, immediately swarmed towards the crowd as it inched eastwards towards Westminster. Flora, 12, who took the coach with her friend Leah, also 12, said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve come down to join the protest because I don‚Äôt agree with Brexit. I have family in France and it‚Äôs going to be much harder to see them if we leave. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really sad because one of my best friends from school has moved to Germany, because she didn‚Äôt like what was happening here.‚Äù Leah, meanwhile, said that while her mum had voted to leave and her dad had backed remain, she wanted her future to be in Europe. Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, will address the crowd later today. He told Sky earlier that calls for a second vote should not be confused with support for ‚Äúneverendums‚Äù, arguing that politicians could not be trusted to make the right decision. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt think of anything more democratic or British than trusting the British people,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSome of the promises made two years ago have not materialised. Nobody was talking about a bad deal, or no deal whatsoever. The public should have a say on the outcomes, with the option of staying in the EU ‚ÄúJeremy Corbyn and Labour are quite clear, all the options should remain on the table. But the prime minister can‚Äôt get her own cabinet to agree, let alone her party. ‚ÄúNobody was saying we won‚Äôt have access to the single market, nobody was talking about damaging the NHS, and so we should ask the British public, with the option of staying in the EU. ‚ÄúAs it is now, the NHS is stockpiling medicine, our police are planning for civil unrest, our prime minister can‚Äôt get a deal through cabinet. Let the people have a say,‚Äù he added. Campaigners are being led to Parliament Square by a group of young voters behind a People‚Äôs Vote banner. Emma Stevens and Emily Longman are two of the students leading the march and are among the hundreds of thousands of young people who were denied a vote in the referendum but must now live with the consequences. Longman, 20, said she was four months too young to vote in the referendum. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre both Spanish students due to study abroad next year, but no one knows what will happen with Erasmus funding,‚Äù she said. Stevens, also 20, said: ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want the other European countries to hold the same view [of leaving the EU].‚Äù While anti-Brexit protesters gathered for the People‚Äôs Vote march, Theresa May visited an art exhibition in her constituency of Maidenhead. Titled Maidenhead and Me, the exhibition featured work by locals with different perspectives of the town. One of the works was called Bridge Over Troubled Brexit Waters and depicted May carrying a cross over a river of bad Brexit headlines. Here‚Äôs the prime minister perusing the gallery last month. Marching under an ‚ÄúIslanders for Europe‚Äù sign, Glenn Kobanny said he had travelled from the Isle of Wight this morning to be part of the protest. The 52-year-old, originally from the island, said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a load of nonsense, it was a bunch of lies to begin with. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry that people fell for the lies but we speak to leavers as much as we talk to remainers and they‚Äôre just as fed up with it as well.‚Äù Meanwhile, ahead of a Leave means Leave rally in Harrogate, Nigel Farage has told Sky that he would be happy to have a second referendum. Recent polling has showed that 46% of the public believe that, in hindsight, Britain was wrong to vote to leave the European Union. Conversely, 43% of people thought the UK was right to leave. Campaigners also hope to unleash a tide of postal protest aimed at MPs by issuing 100,000 postcards emblazoned with the words ‚ÄúBrexit has already become a dog‚Äôs dinner ‚Äì the whole process is going badly wrong. And it‚Äôs only going to get worse.‚Äù A spokesman for The People‚Äôs Vote said it was time to tell politicians they will not be forgiven ‚Äúif they allow a bad deal to be rammed through parliament‚Äù or ‚Äúblindfold the public about the long-term cost of Brexit‚Äù. You can read the full story behind today‚Äôs protest by our Brexit correspondent Lisa O‚ÄôCarroll here: Jo Steele, who works at St Michael‚Äôs and All Saints charity, estimates that more than 250 people have come down from Oxford to join the march. ‚ÄúWe support the EU, we want to remain in the EU, and we are marching for democracy,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe need a further referendum on the final deal with the option to remain.‚Äù She described the possibility of a no deal as a ‚Äútotal disaster‚Äù, warning the UK may well sleep walk into it. ‚ÄúNegotiations aren‚Äôt going anywhere. Theresa May isn‚Äôt in control of her cabinet, her party and the country.‚Äù Demonstrators are now marching along the eastern edge of Hyde Park. They are expected to turn on to Piccadilly, before proceeding along St James Street and Pall Mall to get to Trafalgar Square. Protesters will head down Whitehall, past Downing Street, before eventually gathering in Parliament Square where speeches in support of a people‚Äôs vote will be held from 2pm. Here are some photos from earlier today: The Labour MP David Lammy, one of the most vocal proponents of a second vote, has urged people not to accept the idea that it is impossible to stop Brexit. Lammy has been increasingly critical of the Brexit negotiations and has publicly lambasted key Brexiteers for alleged conflicts of interest. Around 400 protesters made up of British expatriates living in Europe, some of whom travelled from Italy and France, and EU citizens residing in the UK have gathered in Hyde Park to call for the right to vote in a final referendum. The group have united under the umbrella group the Five Million, which refers to the number of EU citizens in Britain and UK citizens residing in the EU. Protesters chanted ‚Äúwe are the three million‚Äù in English, Spanish, Italian, French and German. They also called for the ‚ÄúBrexit bus to crash‚Äù Kalba Meadows, a coordinator of Remain in France Together and a member of the British in Europe‚Äôs steering committee, travelled from French Pyrenees to join the march. ‚ÄúI am here for two reasons: I‚Äôm here to show how strong we are as a group and celebrate everything we‚Äôve done together over the last two years,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI am here because we‚Äôve been disenfranchised from the referendum. I am here to demand that the people most affected by Brexit actually have a say in what happens.‚Äù Axel Antoni, 44, a spokesperson for the campaign group 3 Million, said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very specific demand: we want a final say for all. the UK is our home. We are part of it. EU citizens didn‚Äôt even have a vote last time, we didn‚Äôt have a voice last time.‚Äù Thousands of people from across the country have converged on the capital to demand a final say on the terms of the Brexit deal. The People‚Äôs Vote March is due to set off from Park Lane at midday and will end in a rally in Parliament Square. The London mayor, Sadiq Khan, and the celebrity chef Delia Smith are among those due to speak at the event, while the Green party MP Caroline Lucas and the human rights campaigner Peter Tatchell tweeted from where protesters are gathering. Simon Chater is part of the Devon for Europe group, which arranged eight coaches to bring campaigners to London for the event. The 69-year-old from South Devon said: ‚ÄúThis is the first time in my life I‚Äôve been political.‚Äù The march comes as the Brexit negotiations enter a crucial stage, with deep splits in both the main parties fuelling uncertainty over whether the government will be able to command enough support in parliament to ratify any deal it agrees with the EU27.

fields.trailText: Newcastle could find no answer to Beram Kayal‚Äôs first-half goal that secured Brighton a 1-0 win at St James‚Äô Park
fields.byline: Louise Taylor at St James' Park
fields.body:
Mike Ashley does not really do regrets but, in a rare moment of introspection, Newcastle‚Äôs owner did recently offer a public apology to Chris Hughton for sacking him eight years ago.

It was a particularly harsh dismissal and only served to deepen the affection of Tynesiders for the popular man they dubbed ‚ÄúComrade Chris‚Äù in recognition of his leftwing politics.

Related: √ârik Lamela the star as Tottenham hold on for narrow win at West Ham

Four managers and a relegation later, Ashley has the top-notch Rafael Ben√≠tez in charge but will most definitely not have enjoyed watching the decorated Spaniard outmanoeuvred by Hughton‚Äôs Brighton on another dreadful day for Newcastle.

An already appalling ‚Äì and winless ‚Äì start to the season was further compounded by a fifth straight home defeat that left Newcastle with only two points and contemplating a long, hard winter.

Granted, it took a deflected goal from a dubious corner and some fine goalkeeping from Mathew Ryan for Brighton to win it, but the boos at the final whistle reflected the reality that Newcastle lacked the creativity to prevent themselves from being sent to the bottom of the table.

The game was swiftly halted for several minutes while Brighton‚Äôs Glenn Murray received treatment on the pitch following a nasty clash of heads with Federico Fern√°ndez. After a worrying hiatus, Murray was taken straight to the nearby Royal Victoria Infirmary with medical staff stretchering him straight to an emergency exit in a corner of the ground, where an ambulance waited.

At half-time Brighton reported that the striker was fully conscious in hospital and undergoing precautionary scans, but when play resumed the mood had turned sombre. It took a while for Newcastle to recapture an early momentum that had seen Ryan spread himself adroitly before saving superbly from Ayoze P√©rez after Jonjo Shelvey had dispossessed a slapdash Ga√´tan Bong.

Up in the directors‚Äô box, Ashley seemed to curse Ryan‚Äôs heroics. After neglecting to watch Ben√≠tez‚Äôs team for over a year, he was attending his fourth match in a row. He does not seems to be bringing his players much luck.

Indeed since rediscovering an apparent enthusiasm for the club ‚Äì although it could merely be a case of the proprietor taking the temperature around Ben√≠tez and his side ‚Äì Ashley has not had an awful lot to cheer about.

He witnessed another setback when Brighton‚Äôs Iran international Alireza Jahanbakhsh floated in a disputed corner. It was flicked on by Shane Duffy for Jos√© Izquierdo to unleash a volley that took a slight deflection off the Israel midfielder Beram Kayal on its route past Martin Dubravka.

Related: Southampton hold Bournemouth but Manolo Gabbiadini blows chance of win

Kayal‚Äôs goal offered confirmation that Newcastle had been seriously unsettled by Murray‚Äôs injury but their protests over the awardance of the corner seemed to galvanise them once more. results.webTitle: Roberto Pereyra strikes as Watford stun Wolves with two goals in one minute

fields.headline: Roberto Pereyra strikes as Watford stun Wolves with two goals in one minute
fields.trailText: √âtienne Capoue and Roberto Pereyra were both on target as two goals in 58 seconds gave Watford a 2-0 win at Wolves
fields.body:
Just when Wolves supporters thought this Premier League lark was easy. Two goals in 58 seconds during the first half from √âtienne Capoue and Roberto Pereyra inflicted their first home defeat since January to offer Nuno Esp√≠rito Santo‚Äôs side a timely reality check.

The Wolves manager had named an unchanged side in the league for the ninth match in a row ‚Äì a run that had seen them go six matches unbeaten, conceding only six goals and picking up 15 points. By contrast, Watford seemed to have spiralled into the kind of form that they usually reserve for the end of the season: after winning their first four matches in such style, they‚Äôd picked up just a solitary point since beating Tottenham at the start of September. There was no place for captain Troy Deeney in the squad due to a hamstring injury, meaning Javi Gracia handed opportunities to Gerard Deulofeu and Isaac Success in attack, while there was a first league start for Italian Adam Masina at left-back.

It all pointed to another home victory for a team that has been described as the best promoted side in Premier League history by Jamie Redknapp, but, in Pereyra and Abdoulaye Doucour√©, Watford possess two players who would grace almost any team in the division. The Argentina international prompted the opening goal, with his pass to Doucour√© then setting up Capoue for a daisy cutter from 30 yards. His shot deceived Rui Patr√≠cio after squeezing through the legs of Conor Coady.

Wolves barely had time to react before it was 2-0. The dominant Doucour√© won the ball back and then was on hand to deliver another assist as Pereyra guided a sublime finish past Patr√≠cio with the outside of his left foot. It could have got even worse for Wolves had Lee Mason adjudged that Success had been brought down inside the box in a marginal decision but, to Esp√≠rito Santo‚Äôs relief, the referee instead signalled for a free-kick.

The hosts continued to stick to the principles that have brought such rewards so far this season yet they barely troubled Ben Foster in the Watford goal, as Doucour√© and Capoue continued to control the midfield. They simply had to improve, and the introduction of Ruben Vinagre as a second-half substitute saw Foster at last called into action to palm away a dangerous looking cross.

For obvious reasons given his West Brom associations, the goalkeeper was a target for away fans in the second half but he had to be alert to deny Willy Boly‚Äôs attempted backheel on the hour mark. After that, he was rarely troubled. A lightning-quick break instigated by Pererya then almost settled the game for good, only for R√∫ben Neves to deny Doucour√© what would have been a deserved goal with a brilliant tackle at the last.

Espirito Santo turned to super sub Adama Traor√© in a bid to rouse his players, but it was Ivan Caveleiro who wasted the best opportunity when he headed over from 10 yards. H√©lder Costa also blazed over from inside the box as Watford held on to record their first win in four league games and climb above Wolves in the table.

results.webTitle: √ârik Lamela the star as Tottenham hold on for narrow win at West Ham

fields.headline: √ârik Lamela the star as Tottenham hold on for narrow win at West Ham
fields.trailText: √ârik Lamela‚Äôs goal was enough as Tottenham held on for a 1-0 win at West Ham
fields.byline: David Hytner at the London Stadium
fields.body:
Tottenham‚Äôs best ever start to a Premier League season goes on, even if they continue to give the impression that they have yet to hit their stride. They were the better team here and had the best player on show in √ârik Lamela, whose cute first-half header proved the difference.

One thing is clear. It is a good sign for Mauricio Pochettino and the club that they are winning without truly dazzling. This game marked the start of a gruelling run of seven matches in 21 days and Spurs will need all of their powers of endurance as they resume on Wednesday at PSV Eindhoven in a must-win Champions League tie.

Related: Brighton‚Äôs Beram Kayal scrambles home to send abject Newcastle rock bottom

Lamela is not an automatic selection; this was his first Premier League start of the season. But he is becoming increasingly influential and he now has five goals from eight appearances in all competitions.

West Ham pushed in the second half, after failing to show up in the first period, but Marko Arnautovic ‚Äì their shining light ‚Äì could not find a way past Hugo Lloris. After the encouraging draw against Chelsea and the victory over Manchester United, there had been the shoots of hope at the London Stadium. But this was not a day for them to remember.

This is usually described as the big one for West Ham, even if Tottenham do not feel the same way. However it did not feel like a big game, at times, with the atmosphere subdued for long spells. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs happened to your stadium?‚Äù the Spurs fans wanted to know during the first half, or words to that effect. There was not much by way of response from the home crowd. As endlessly discussed and lamented, the London Stadium is not the cauldron that Upton Park once was.

Tottenham flickered during a slow-burning start, with Moussa Sissoko watching a deflected effort loop off target and Harry Kane denied by an Issa Diop slide tackle after Lucas Moura‚Äôs through-ball.

Sissoko started on the right of Pochettino‚Äôs midfield three and he had some nice moments, none better than the jink inside Felipe Anderson followed by the left-footed cross that ushered in Lamela to break the deadlock. The delivery was perfect; Lamela‚Äôs finish ruthless. Spurs might have been further in front at half-time but, after pushing out Lamela‚Äôs cross, Lukasz Fabianski got down to deny Davinson S√°nchez at close quarters.

Related: Roberto Pereyra strikes as Watford stun Wolves with two goals in one minute

West Ham could not get going before the interval ‚Äì Anderson was particularly poor ‚Äì while they also suffered the loss of Andriy Yarmolenko. The winger got his studs stuck in the turf as he attempted to chase a ball following a corner and it was an ugly twist that left him writhing in agony.

Lamela was excellent, catching the eye with his flair and acceleration, not to mention his industry while at the other end, Arnautovic was central to everything that West Ham did.

The home side were better in the second half, playing with a greater intensity, which was summed up when Arnautovic jumped into a slide challenge to dispossess S√°nchez as Spurs attempted to play out from the back. Arnautovic and S√°nchez squared up and that got the juices going.

Arnautovic went close to the equaliser on three occasions only to be denied by Lloris. First, he directed a looping header from Aaron Cresswell‚Äôs cross towards the top corner only for the goalkeeper to claw to safety at full stretch while shortly afterwards, he shot low and true but Lloris touched around the far post. At the very end, Arnautovic wriggled free of S√°nchez only for Lloris to leave his line and block.

results.webTitle: Manchester City hammer Burnley with Leroy San√© adding the finishing touch

fields.headline: Manchester City hammer Burnley with Leroy San√© adding the finishing touch
fields.trailText: Manchester City had five different scorers as they thrashed Burnley 5-0 at the Etihad Stadium
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at the Etihad Stadium
fields.body:
Raheem Sterling was an unused substitute in this game, granted a rest after rediscovering his scoring touch with England. It might not do him any harm to realise how well Manchester City can operate without him, especially against sides as limited as Burnley.

With Pep Guardiola sending on his other substitutes Kevin de Bruyne and Phil Foden for cameo appearances in the second half everyone in blue was happy in the end. The only possible complaint was that City might have won by an even greater margin, such was their total control, though when Riyad Mahrez and Leroy San√© added stylish goals in the closing minutes it hardly seemed to matter.

Related: Chelsea‚Äôs late leveller against Manchester United sparks touchline chaos around Mourinho

Sergio Ag√ºero always scores against Burnley, he went into this game with six goals from six meetings, and it took him a mere 17 minutes to make it seven in seven. He could have scored much earlier than that, but the first time Mahrez arrowed in a diagonal cross from the right, after four minutes, the striker seemed to lose his bearings and put a free header uncharacteristically wide.

That should have been a warning to Burnley to get tighter to City‚Äôs main goal threat, yet the next time it happened Ag√ºero met Mahrez‚Äôs cross with his foot and Joe Hart was obliged to make a point-blank save. Ag√ºero acknowledged his former teammate‚Äôs reactions with a friendly pat on the back, though there was to be no respite for the returning goalkeeper. David Silva and San√© traded passes in the penalty area as they waited for an opening to present itself, and when it did Ag√ºero had no trouble in holding off Charlie Taylor to reach Silva‚Äôs cross and beat Hart with a low shot.

City continued to make good progress down the left, where the trickiness of David Silva and San√© was backed up by an overlapping Benjamin Mendy breaching the Burnley backline on numerous occasions. Yet with the visitors rarely crossing halfway there was little urgency to the home side‚Äôs attacks. Several promising situations were wasted and no more goals were added before half-time. Significantly the closest City came to extending their lead, when Mahrez found the side netting after half an hour, was a result of Ederson instigating a direct attack by sending Bernardo Silva through the middle with a composed and precise pass.

Pep Guardiola has often complained his side are nowhere near clinical enough when on top, and the City manager was visibly frustrated right at the end of the first half when Hart managed a one-handed stop to keep out David Silva‚Äôs header and Ag√ºero missed an open goal from the rebound from a distance of no more than a yard.

All Burnley had to offer before the interval was a good run by Jack Cork that led to Jeff Hendrick seeing a shot blocked by John Stones, though their most promising opening came in the opening minute following a mistake by Aymeric Laporte. Vincent Kompany managed to snuff out the danger at the expense of a yellow card for a dangerously high tackle on Aaron Lennon. Starting a league game for the first time since August, the City captain found himself in the book just 35 seconds in.

The bombardment Hart must have been expecting all week arrived early in the second half with two goals in just over two minutes. The initial breakthrough came as a result of quick thinking by David Silva, who noticed as Jon Moss theatrically denied San√© a penalty after a collision with Cork that the loose ball was not running out of play as the Burnley defenders seemed to be expecting.

Related: Cardiff‚Äôs Kadeem Harris secures victory against a Fulham in freefall

With the visitors standing still as if the game had been stopped, Silva played to the whistle, reached the ball unopposed and crossed for Bernardo Silva to score. Burnley were so stunned they conceded again from the next corner, Ben Mee only managing a half clearance which simply allowed Fernandinho to crash a piledriving shot through a crowded penalty area.

Evidently convinced the game was now safe, Guardiola sent on De Bruyne for the last half hour to enormous applause. This probably looked like unnecessary cruelty to Burnley and their supporters, though in fact it was Phil Foden, a later substitute for David Silva, who caught the eye. The teenage England prospect played the slickest of one-twos with Mahrez to find space down the right for a cross that Gabriel Jesus headed straight at Hart. Foden and De Bruyne combined seven minutes from the end in the move that led to Mahrez‚Äôs goal.

San√© appeared to have wasted an excellent shooting opportunity by looking for a pass instead, but Mahrez rescued the situation by gathering the stray ball and beating Hart with an exquisite curling shot from just outside the area. When San√© added a fifth at the death with a first-time finish from Mendy‚Äôs cross, Hart was left kicking a goalpost in frustration. As someone who knows both these clubs extremely well, he cannot have been all that surprised.

results.webTitle: Khashoggi mourners demand justice as Congress urges full US investigation

fields.headline: Khashoggi mourners demand justice as Congress urges full US investigation
fields.standfirst: International pressure builds on Saudi Arabia as colleagues of murdered journalist demand punishment for his killers
fields.trailText: International pressure builds on Saudi Arabia as colleagues of murdered journalist demand punishment for his killers
fields.byline: Bethan McKernan in Istanbul and Julian Borger in Washington
fields.body:
Amidst international scorn for Saudi Arabia‚Äôs official explanation of the death of Jamal Khashoggi, friends and colleagues of the reporter on Saturday resumed their vigil outside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, where he was killed two weeks ago.

Related: Saudi Arabia admits Khashoggi killed but claims he died in 'fistfight'

They were there to mourn his death and demand ‚Äútrue justice‚Äù.

In the US, Saudi Arabia‚Äôs major ally, the Trump administration remained cautiously supportive of the Riyadh line. But pressure was building. Bob Corker, chair of the powerful Senate foreign relations committee, doubted the Saudi version of events and said the US ‚Äúmust make its own independent, credible determination of responsibility for Khashoggi‚Äôs murder‚Äù.

After more than two weeks of stubborn denials from Saudi Arabia that it had anything to do with Khashoggi‚Äôs disappearance, statements carried on the state news agency in the early hours of Saturday finally acknowledged his death ‚Äì the result, it said, of a ‚Äúfistfight‚Äù inside the consulate on 2 October.

The statements said 18 men had been arrested in connection with the ‚Äúcover-up‚Äù and two senior officials ‚Äì confidantes of Crown Prince Mohammad Bin Salman ‚Äì had been sacked. Khashoggi‚Äôs body was disposed of by a ‚Äúlocal collaborator‚Äù, officials added.

Khashoggi was a Saudi national but a US permanent resident. Saudi Arabia had been under significant pressure from the White House to offer an explanation in an escalating diplomatic crisis. Its eventual account met with widespread scepticism, however, in the face of mounting evidence from the Turkish investigation into Khashoggi‚Äôs death pointing to a sophisticated assassination operation that could not have been carried out without the sanction of the Saudi royal court.

Turkish officials have coordinated sustained leaks to local and US media that suggest Khashoggi was tortured and murdered and dismembered with a bone saw.

Investigators allege 15 men who arrived in Istanbul from Riyadh on jets owned by the Saudi royal family were sent to kill the reporter. Several of the suspects ‚Äì including members of the crown prince‚Äôs security detail and a forensics expert ‚Äì were captured in security camera footage entering the consulate building on the day Khashoggi died.

On Saturday, Saudi Arabia‚Äôs allies in the region expressed support. The UK, another ally, cautiously acknowledged the Saudi version of events. A statement from the Foreign Office said the government was considering its next steps.

But it was not clear the explanation of Khashoggi‚Äôs murder, the sackings and purported arrests would contain the damage to Riyadh.

At the United Nations, a spokesman said secretary general Ant√≥nio Guterres was ‚Äúdeeply troubled‚Äù and ‚Äústresses the need for a prompt, thorough and transparent investigation into the circumstances of Mr Khashoggi‚Äôs death and full accountability for those responsible‚Äù.

Outside government circles, Amnesty International called for ‚Äúan impartial and independent investigation by the UN‚Äù.

fields.headline: On the verge of F1 greatness: now Lewis Hamilton targets glamorous new empire
fields.standfirst: He is racing to clinch his fifth title ‚Äì but now there‚Äôs his fashion and music too

fields.body:
In two social media posts last week, the British racing driver Lewis Hamilton showed where he has come from and how far he has travelled. The first was a link to an eight-minute Blue Peter tribute, in which he appears for approximately two seconds. The feature was on radio-controlled cars and Hamilton displays a focus and determination that would prove handy in later life by thrashing presenter John Leslie. He was seven at the time, living with his mum on an estate in Stevenage. ‚ÄúRemember being on Blue Peter like it was yesterday,‚Äù the 33-year-old wrote on Twitter.

In the next post, Hamilton is in New York, filming himself last week on his phone in front of a giant billboard on which he appears in full racing garb. ‚ÄúMamma I made it,‚Äù he comments, ‚Äúthat‚Äôs me on the Nasdaq building in Times Square.‚Äù

Hamilton certainly has made it. Already he is a four-time Formula One champion, as well as Britain‚Äôs wealthiest sportsperson (his fortune is estimated at about ¬£130m). And on Sunday, just after 7pm, he will set out to claim his fifth title at the US Grand Prix in Austin, Texas. If Hamilton wins and Sebastian Vettel finishes in third place or lower, the crown will be his.

Vettel will be stiffer competition than Leslie, no doubt, but Hamilton ‚Äì with nine race wins already this season in his Mercedes ‚Äì has been close to unstoppable in 2018. History appears to be on his side, too: of the six grands prix held in Austin, he has won five. One more statistic: in total, Hamilton has recorded 71 race wins in Formula One and it seems only a matter of time before he overhauls Michael Schumacher‚Äôs record of 91 career victories. If that happens, who could deny that Hamilton is a contender for the greatest Formula One driver ever? Last week, his long-time rival Fernando Alonso named him in his all-time top five.

Hamilton may live in Monte Carlo these days, and his voice has a distinct Anglo-American twang, but he has clearly not forgotten where it all started. His Blue Peter experience is one example, and often in interviews he talks fondly of his early days driving karts, marvelling at how unlikely it is that someone from his background ‚Äì and his ethnicity ‚Äì could break into the privileged, very white world of Formula One.

‚ÄúI grew up seeing kids arriving in helicopters and stuff,‚Äù he recalled recently, at the launch in Tokyo of his new fashion collection with Tommy Hilfiger. ‚ÄúMe and my dad were in our Fiat Cinquecento and they were turning up in their Lamborghinis.‚Äù

Hamilton added that he hopes it will still be possible for the ‚Äúdiamonds in the rough‚Äù to come through in Formula One. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt beat that raw natural hunger,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf I had a kid right now he would have such an easy life, and there is no way he is going to be as hungry as me.‚Äù

Seeing Hamilton showering his rivals with champagne on the podium every fortnight, it can be easy to forget what an unlikely journey he has had. His father Anthony is the child of Grenadian immigrants, his mother Carmen is white British; they separated when Lewis ‚Äì named after the sprinter Carl Lewis ‚Äì was two. Everyone agrees that Hamilton was a natural at karting, but his father had to take redundancy from British Rail to chaperone him to races. In the gaps, he did three jobs, including putting up ‚Äúfor sale‚Äù signs for a local estate agent.

Hamilton first signed a deal with McLaren aged 13, but still his rise was not entirely straightforward. He was expelled from his Catholic secondary school before his GCSEs and then reinstated, a case of mistaken identity when another pupil was hospitalised after a fight. And even when his path to Formula One seemed anointed, his father made him take a summer job valeting cars at a Mercedes dealership (apparently he was excellent, reliably meticulous).

Two things have been consistent since Hamilton made his Formula One debut in 2007: he has always been fast and he has never been far from controversy. Last year his name came up in the Paradise Papers data leak, accused of avoiding a ¬£3.3m VAT bill on his candy apple-coloured Bombardier private jet by using offshore shell companies. He became embroiled in another embarrassing incident on Christmas Day when he posted a video on Instagram of a conversation with his four-year-old nephew. The boy proudly wore a frilly pink dress until Hamilton shrieked, ‚ÄúWhy are you wearing a princess dress? Boys don‚Äôt wear princess dresses!‚Äù His nephew then ran from the room.

The repercussions were swift: social media outrage from LGBTQ and anti-bullying groups; an apology from Hamilton, followed by a speedy erasing of all his social media posts, starting with a clean slate on 1 January (he has 7.6 million followers on Instagram; 5.4 million on Twitter). When he launched his menswear line with Hilfiger, called TommyXLewis, one of the key pieces was a patchwork tartan kilt. He appeared on the cover of the August issue of men‚Äôs magazine GQ pointedly wearing it, under the line, ‚ÄúI want to make amends‚Äù.

To me he seemed like a young man blessed with good intentions and cursed with a severe lack of guidance

Teo van den Broeke, GQ magazine

GQ‚Äôs style director Teo van den Broeke, who wrote the story, described meeting him in a follow-up piece on the magazine‚Äôs website. ‚ÄúI came away from the interview feeling conflicted about Hamilton,‚Äù he noted. ‚ÄúAlmost everyone I spoke to beforehand has some kind of opinion on him ‚Äì negative, more often than not ‚Äì but to me he seemed like a young man blessed with good intentions and cursed with a severe lack of guidance.‚Äù

There seems more strict guidance these days: his social media posts certainly have a feelgood vibe with a sprinkling of glamour (riding a quad bike in the Dubai desert with rapper Nicki Minaj, who may or may not be his girlfriend).

But for now, Hamilton is concentrating on the track; he has extended his contract with Mercedes for two more years, which pays about $50m (¬£38m) a year. He must have Schumacher‚Äôs record in his sights. He has also signed up to do four collections with Hilfiger. And he dipped his toe into music this summer, featuring on the Christina Aguilera track Pipe, under the pseudonym XNDA.

Somehow, you can‚Äôt imagine Hamilton killing time before settling down in the commentary box. As he acknowledged at his fashion launch in Tokyo, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm definitely trying to build an empire.‚Äù
